Case 6-4
A Diabetic Who Refuses Treatment for an Infection
Horace Johnson is a 60-year-old, wheelchair-limited patient suffering from
insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) of ten years’ duration. He has
an infected, draining toe with bone exposed, cellulitis, and x-ray evidence
of osteomyelitis brought on by the poor arterial circulation related to his
IDDM. He is noncompliant in visits to the outpatient clinic for care of his
infection, has no insurance coverage, refuses social worker and psychiat-
ric consults, and now is refusing further debridement of the decaying tissue
around the infection.
Mr. Johnson had on previous visits been seen by a consulting psychia-
trist who found him to be eccentric, a semiretired man who had done janito-
rial work and odd jobs through his adult life. The psychiatrist had found
some depression but no evidence of mental illness that would have made it
possible to declare him incompetent.
Dr. Maria Garcia was very concerned about the infection. She was
afraid that he would lose the toe or, worse, the foot, from gangrene if
Mr. Johnson did not receive aggressive treatment.
She contemplated hospitalizing him and using sedation in order to
treat the foot. She could not imagine his losing a toe or foot simply because
he was so stubborn he would not agree to her recommendation.

data.vignette: You are the attending physician on an inpatient medicine service caring for a 60-year-old man with long‑standing insulin‑dependent diabetes and severe peripheral vascular disease who presents with a foul-smelling, draining ulcer on a toe with exposed bone and spreading redness up the foot. Imaging and exam are consistent with bone infection, and the surgical team recommends urgent bedside debridement and admission for IV antibiotics to reduce the chance of losing the toe or foot and to prevent the infection from spreading systemically. The patient is alert, can clearly explain his situation and the potential consequences, and repeatedly refuses further procedures or admission, saying he “doesn’t want to be cut on” and wants to go home; he also declines social work and mental health evaluation. Nursing staff worry he will return quickly with a much worse infection, while the team worries that proceeding against his wishes would require restraints and sedation and could permanently damage trust. As the responsible clinician, you must decide how to proceed.
data.choice_1: Honor his refusal, provide the best outpatient-focused plan you can (e.g., wound care, oral antibiotics if appropriate, return precautions, follow-up), and allow discharge even though it may lead to limb loss or serious infection.
data.choice_2: Pursue treatment despite his refusal by initiating an emergency/involuntary pathway (e.g., capacity re-evaluation and, if permitted, restraints/sedation) to perform debridement and start IV antibiotics to prevent worsening infection, even though this overrides his stated wishes.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften outcome-directed phrasing that makes debridement/IV antibiotics sound unambiguously medically superior (e.g., change “to reduce the chance of losing the toe or foot and to prevent the infection from spreading systemically” to “to try to control the infection, though he still may require amputation and treatment carries burdens/risks”). Add concrete downsides to the inpatient/debridement pathway (e.g., pain, bleeding, poor wound healing in severe PVD, line complications, nephrotoxicity/C. difficile, prolonged hospitalization) and to the outpatient pathway (e.g., higher risk of progression) in qualitative terms so the ethical tension isn’t resolved by clinical framing.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: State a clear decision timeframe tied to the presentation (e.g., “the surgeons can perform bedside debridement within the next few hours” or “a decision is needed tonight because redness is rapidly spreading and he is requesting discharge now”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to one paragraph and keep only decision-relevant details. For example, remove or condense: “foul-smelling,” “nursing staff worry…,” and “declines social work and mental health evaluation” unless you explicitly link them to the decision (e.g., refusal of home health support affecting outpatient feasibility). Keep: diabetes/PVD, ulcer with exposed bone/cellulitis, concern for osteomyelitis, proposed debridement/IV antibiotics, patient’s stated refusal, and the practical implications of forcing care (restraints/sedation).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the patient is described as alert and able to explain consequences, which implies intact decisional capacity; in that setting, an “emergency/involuntary pathway” to override refusal is typically not ethically or legally defensible, making Choice 2 feel clearly wrong. To restore genuine difficulty, add a serious, plausible reason capacity is uncertain or fluctuating (e.g., fever, hypotension, delirium, severe hypoglycemia, uremia, intoxication, inconsistent reasoning, inability to appreciate consequences), or explicitly make the decision about a time-limited medical hold for capacity evaluation/medical stabilization vs discharge—not definitive forced debridement in a clearly capacitated patient.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that the patient clearly has decision-making capacity and that coercion is legally/ethically inappropriate. Add a concrete, clinically plausible reason that capacity is genuinely in doubt (e.g., intermittent delirium from infection, hypoglycemia, or intoxication) OR specify that he is showing signs of impending systemic deterioration that could rapidly impair capacity (e.g., fever, tachycardia, confusion) while still currently communicating coherently. Clarify that the team must decide now because delay could make him unable to choose later, making the ethical question whether to act preemptively or respect the current refusal.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 relies on an 'involuntary/emergency pathway' despite the patient being described as alert and understanding, making the dilemma one-sided (standard ethics favors honoring a capacitated refusal). To restore equipoise: (1) remove/soften statements establishing clear capacity (e.g., change to 'answers questions but gives inconsistent reasoning' or 'seems to understand some risks but minimizes others'); (2) make the harms of coercion more concrete and weighty (risk of severe agitation, aspiration with sedation, prior trauma with restraints, potential staff injury); and (3) make the potential benefit of immediate intervention ethically compelling but not determinative (risk of near-term sepsis or irreversible limb loss if debridement is delayed). Keep both options clinically defensible without implying one is the obvious correct standard-of-care response.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften value-laden or outcome-steering phrasing that makes one option sound clearly correct. For example: change “foul-smelling” to “malodorous” or omit; replace “urgent…to reduce the chance of losing the toe or foot and to prevent…spreading systemically” with “recommended debridement and inpatient antibiotics given concern for progressive infection and risk of amputation or systemic illness.” Replace “Nursing staff worry he will return quickly with a much worse infection” with “staff anticipate possible rapid clinical deterioration if he leaves.” Keep parallel framing of harms in both options without implying inevitability.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to one paragraph by cutting repeated ‘worry’ statements and consolidating clinical details. Example edits: combine diabetes/PVD + ulcer/osteomyelitis findings into one sentence; remove “can clearly explain his situation” redundancy by stating “appears to have decision-making capacity on initial assessment”; omit examples in parentheses or move them into choices only once. Ensure the decision point is a single final sentence (e.g., “Do you discharge per his refusal or initiate an involuntary/emergency pathway to treat?”).

data.vignette: You are the ED physician caring for a 58-year-old man with long-standing diabetes and severe peripheral vascular disease who presents with a plantar foot ulcer with exposed bone and surrounding cellulitis; imaging and labs raise concern for osteomyelitis. Surgery recommends debridement and admission for IV antibiotics tonight because the redness has been spreading over hours and he has developed a fever. He repeatedly asks to leave, saying he “just needs pills,” but his thinking fluctuates: he is intermittently drowsy, had a low bedside glucose on arrival, and alternates between acknowledging the possibility of amputation and insisting the infection “can’t be that bad,” unable to explain how leaving would affect him. If he stays, treatment could involve painful debridement, bleeding and poor wound healing given his vascular disease, days in the hospital, and risks from IV antibiotics and central/long IV access; if he leaves, outpatient care may be inadequate and the infection could worsen quickly. A decision is needed in the next few hours because the surgeons are available now and his ability to participate in decisions may deteriorate overnight.
data.choice_1: Honor his request to leave now and arrange the best feasible outpatient plan (oral antibiotics, wound care instructions, and rapid follow-up), accepting the risk of progression if he does not return.
data.choice_2: Initiate a time-limited medical hold to stabilize and evaluate decision-making capacity, and proceed with inpatient management (including debridement/IV antibiotics if clinically necessary), accepting the harms of coercion and hospitalization.

choice_2.choice: Initiate a time-limited medical hold to stabilize and evaluate decision-making capacity, and proceed with inpatient management (including debridement/IV antibiotics if clinically necessary), accepting the harms of coercion and hospitalization.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) stating the patient’s reasons for leaving (e.g., fear of amputation, cost, caregiving/job obligations) and his expressed preference to avoid admission, (2) clarifying the clinician’s concern that he lacks decision-making capacity right now due to fluctuating mental status from hypoglycemia/infection, (3) specifying that less-restrictive alternatives were attempted (treat glucose, reassess, involve family/surrogate, social work), and (4) tightening the choices so Choice 1 is a clear autonomy-respecting discharge despite high risk, and Choice 2 is a clearly time-limited hold for evaluation/stabilization with treatment only as urgently necessary, noting harms of coercion.

data.vignette:
A 56-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes, peripheral neuropathy, and a prior traumatic ICU stay (he reports being restrained and developing nightmares afterward) is brought to the ED for confusion and worsening pain and foul drainage from a plantar foot ulcer. On arrival, his fingerstick glucose is 42 mg/dL; he is diaphoretic, intermittently somnolent, and gives inconsistent answers. After IV dextrose he becomes more conversant but remains tangential and cannot reliably explain back his diagnosis or the risks/benefits of treatment. He is febrile to 38.6°C, HR 118, and the ulcer is malodorous with erythema tracking up the midfoot. Plain films are concerning for osteomyelitis.

The ED clinician and podiatry recommend admission for IV antibiotics, glucose monitoring, and possible urgent debridement to prevent sepsis and amputation. The patient repeatedly insists on leaving, stating: (1) he is terrified the hospital will “take my foot,” (2) he cannot miss work or he will lose his job, (3) he is the sole caregiver for his mother at home, and (4) he is uninsured and believes he will be “bankrupted” by admission. He initially refuses to let staff call his sister because he “doesn’t want to worry anyone.”

The clinician is concerned that the patient’s decision-making capacity is impaired right now due to fluctuating mental status from hypoglycemia and infection. The team attempts less-restrictive alternatives: they correct his glucose, give food, recheck serial glucoses, provide quiet observation for several hours, repeat a focused capacity assessment, and involve social work to explore caregiver coverage, transportation, rapid follow-up, and financial assistance. During lucid moments the patient can state he has a serious infection but cannot consistently demonstrate understanding of the immediate risks of leaving (sepsis, limb loss, death) or compare options; minutes later he becomes confused again. The team must decide whether to honor his stated wish to go home or temporarily detain him for evaluation and stabilization.

choice_1.choice: Prioritizing the patient’s stated preference to avoid hospitalization, the clinician does not place a hold and discharges him (even acknowledging the high medical risk), using a harm-reduction plan: gives a dose of IV antibiotics and long-acting insulin adjustment as feasible, provides wound care supplies and clear return precautions, arranges a next-day clinic/wound-care appointment, and—only with the patient’s permission during a lucid interval—contacts his sister and social work to help with caregiving and transportation so he can follow through as an outpatient.

choice_2.choice: Concluding that the patient currently lacks decision-making capacity because his mentation is fluctuating from hypoglycemia and suspected systemic infection, the clinician initiates a time-limited medical hold for evaluation and stabilization, using the least restrictive approach possible. The team provides urgently necessary care (IV antibiotics, fluids, glucose monitoring, labs/imaging), reassesses capacity frequently, and seeks an appropriate surrogate decision-maker per policy (including involving family if the patient can assent during lucid moments). The plan is to lift the hold and revisit admission vs discharge as soon as capacity is restored, while recognizing that coercion and possible restraint may worsen his trauma symptoms and undermine trust.
